A comprehensive demo of markdown and MDX features available in this blog template

import { useState } from 'react'; # Markdown and MDX Features Demo This post demonstrates the various markdown and MDX features available in this blog template. ## Basic Formatting You can use **bold text**, _italic text_, and `inline code`. You can also create [links](https://astro.build) and add ~~strikethrough~~ text. ## Lists ### Unordered Lists - Item one - Item two - Nested item - Another nested item - Item three ### Ordered Lists 1. First item 2. Second item 1. Nested numbered item 2. Another nested numbered item 3. Third item ## Code Blocks Here's a JavaScript code block with syntax highlighting: ```javascript function greet(name) { console.log(`Hello, ${name}!`); return `Welcome to SwyxKit, ${name}`; } const message = greet('Developer'); ``` Here's a CSS example: ```css .dark-mode { background-color: #1a1a1a; color: #ffffff; } .light-mode { background-color: #ffffff; color: #000000; } ``` ## Blockquotes > This is a blockquote. It can span multiple lines and is great for highlighting important information or quotes from other sources. > > You can also have multiple paragraphs in a blockquote. ## Tables | Feature | SvelteKit Version | Astro Version | | ----------- | ----------------- | ------------- | | Performance | Good | Excellent | | Bundle Size | Medium | Small | | SEO | Good | Excellent | | DX | Great | Great | ## Interactive MDX Component Since this is an MDX file, we can include React components directly: export function Counter() { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); return (

This is a React component embedded in MDX!

Count: {count}

); } ## Images You can include images using standard markdown syntax: ![Astro Logo](https://astro.build/assets/press/astro-logo-light-gradient.svg) ## Horizontal Rules You can create horizontal rules with three or more hyphens: --- ## Math (if enabled) You can include mathematical expressions: The Pythagorean theorem: aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ² ## Conclusion This template supports all standard markdown features plus the power of MDX for interactive components. This gives you the flexibility to create both simple blog posts and rich, interactive content. Happy writing! âœ¨
Moving from SvelteKit to Astro + React
Why and how we migrated from SvelteKit + GitHub CMS to Astro + React + Markdown

# Moving from SvelteKit to Astro + React

The original SwyxKit was built with SvelteKit and used GitHub Issues as a CMS. While innovative, this approach had some trade-offs that we wanted to address.

## Why the Change?

### Performance First

Astro's approach to static site generation with selective hydration means faster page loads and better Core Web Vitals scores.

### Simpler Content Management

Using markdown files instead of GitHub Issues provides:

- Easier content authoring
- Better version control integration
- No API rate limits
- Offline development capability

### React Ecosystem

While Svelte is excellent, React's larger ecosystem provides more component libraries and tooling options.

## What We Kept

- The beautiful, minimal design language
- Dark mode toggle functionality
- Fuzzy search capabilities
- Mobile-responsive navigation
- Newsletter signup component
- Featured posts section

## What Changed

- **CMS**: GitHub Issues â†’ Markdown files
- **Framework**: SvelteKit â†’ Astro
- **Components**: Svelte â†’ React (for interactive parts)
- **Comments**: Removed (too complex to migrate)
- **Build**: Faster and more reliable

## Technical Benefits

### Bundle Size

Astro ships zero JavaScript by default, only hydrating interactive components. This results in significantly smaller bundle sizes.

### Development Experience

- Hot module replacement
- TypeScript support out of the box
- Better error messages
- Faster build times

### SEO Improvements

- Better static HTML generation
- Automatic sitemap generation
- RSS feed support
- Improved meta tag handling

## Migration Process

The migration involved:

1. **Content conversion**: Converting GitHub issues to markdown files
2. **Component migration**: Adapting Svelte components to React
3. **Styling preservation**: Maintaining the exact same Tailwind classes
4. **Feature parity**: Ensuring all core functionality remained

## Conclusion

The new Astro + React version maintains everything you loved about the original while providing better performance, simpler content management, and a more maintainable codebase.

The proof is in the performance metrics - try navigating around and feel the difference! ðŸš€

A modern blog template that combines the best of static generation with interactive components

# Welcome to SwyxKit Astro

This is **SwyxKit** reimagined for 2024, now powered by Astro and React while maintaining the beautiful design and user experience of the original SvelteKit template.

## What's New

- âš¡ï¸ **Lightning Fast**: Built with Astro for optimal performance
- âš›ï¸ **Interactive**: React components for dynamic functionality
- ðŸŽ¨ **Beautiful**: Maintains the original SwyxKit design language
- ðŸ“ **Simple CMS**: Uses markdown files instead of GitHub Issues
- ðŸ” **Fuzzy Search**: Fast client-side search functionality
- ðŸŒ™ **Dark Mode**: Toggle between light and dark themes

## Features

This template includes all the great features you loved from the original:

- Responsive design that works on all devices
- Blog post search and filtering
- Featured posts section
- Newsletter signup
- Dark mode toggle
- Reading time estimation
- Tag-based organization
- RSS feed generation

## Getting Started

1. Clone this repository
2. Install dependencies with `npm install`
3. Start the development server with `npm run dev`
4. Begin writing your posts in the `src/content/blog/` directory

## Writing Posts

Create new blog posts by adding markdown files to `src/content/blog/`. Each post should include frontmatter with the required fields:

```yaml
---
title: 'Your Post Title'
description: 'A brief description of your post'
category: 'essay' # or "note"
tags: ['tag1', 'tag2']
date: 2024-01-15
featured: false
draft: false
---
```

## Why Astro?

Astro provides the perfect balance of static site generation performance with the ability to add interactive components where needed. This means:

- **Faster page loads** with mostly static HTML
- **Better SEO** with server-side rendering
- **Selective hydration** for interactive features
- **Smaller JavaScript bundles** compared to full SPA frameworks

Enjoy your new blog! ðŸš€
